name: Count Obeying Bitmasks In The Range
description:
We say that integer a __obeys__ integer b if in all positions where b has bits set to 1, a has corresponding bits set to 1.

For example:
```
1111101 = 125 obeys
1101101 = 109, but
1111000 = 120 does not obey
1101011 = 107.
```

# <span style="color:cyan">Task

Write a function `countObeyingBitmasks` that takes integers `x`, `y`, `z` and returns the number of integers in __the range__ (determined by the inputs, see below) that obey at least one of the inputs.

## <span style="color:cyan">The range determined by the inputs:
`$ [0, 2^{\left\lceil \log_{2}(\max(x,y,z)+1) \right\rceil} )$`

(from zero up to, but not including, the smallest power of two greater than the inputs)

# <span style="color:cyan">Example

For integers:
```
x = 1001 = 9
y = 0011 = 3 and
z = 0110 = 6
```
the function should return 8, since there are 8 integers obeying x, y, or z. Namely:
```
0011 = 3,
0110 = 6,
0111 = 7,
1001 = 9,
1011 = 11
1101 = 13,
1110 = 14,
1111 = 15
```

# <span style="color:cyan"> Note

The inputs can be big (up to a billion), so make your solution efficient.
